questions.question:
Question 1: A patient has developed confusion and keeps bumping into objects. He can speak fluently. 
But on examination, he cannot differentiate between fingers and cannot write. He also gets 
confused with the examiner's right and left sides. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is Gerstmann syndrome. It is commonly associated with 
damage to the left (dominant) inferior parietal lobule. Gerstmann syndrome consists of: • Acalculia - impairment of simple arithmetic • Dysgraphia - impaired writing • Finger anomia - an inability to name individual fingers • Right-left confusion - an inability to tell whether a hand, foot, or arm of the patient or examiner 
is on the right or left side of the body Option B: Anton syndrome also known as visual anosognosia occurs due to bilateral infarction in 
the distal PCAs. It produces cortical blindness and the patients are unaware of the blindness or 
may even deny it. Option C: Millard-Gubler syndrome occurs due to ventral pontine injury. It causes functional loss 
of the 6th and 7th cranial nerves and corticospinal tract. This presents as diplopia, ipsilateral 
facial palsy, ipsilateral loss of corneal reflex, contralateral hemiparesis. Option D: Dejerine-Roussy syndrome is associated with hemisensory loss and severe burning pain 
in the affected region. It is also known as thalamic pain syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 78-year-old woman presents with right hemisensory loss followed by agonizing, burning 
pain in the affected regions. The pain responds poorly to analgesics. These features are 
classically seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
1120 
Sold by @itachibot Hemisensory loss and severe burning pain in the affected regions is classically seen in 
Dejerine-Roussy syndrome, also known as thalamic pain syndrome. Dejerine- Roussy syndrome occurs due to occlusion of the thalamic and thalamogeniculate 
branches arising from the P1 segment resulting in contralateral hemisensory loss and severe 
burning pain in the affected regions. The P1 segment of the posterior cerebral artery extends from the basilar bifurcation to the 
junction with the posterior communicating artery. This pain responds poorly to analgesics. Anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine or gabapentin or 
tricyclic antidepressants may be beneficial.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 73-year-old woman was brought to the OPD since she has been tripping over things at 
home. On entering, she complimented the doctor’s tie even though he was not wearing one 
and continued to insist that she could see normally. On examination, bilateral blindness was 
present but pupillary light reflex was normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of Anton's syndrome. It occurs due to bilateral infarction in the 
distal posterior cerebral artery (P2 segment) and is associated with the following features: • Cortical blindness with preserved pupillary light reaction • Visual anosognosia - denial of loss of vision • Confabulation in the setting of obvious visual loss Option D: Riddoch phenomenon is a condition where cortical blindness is associated with the 
perception of only moving targets.

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient with a history of ischemic heart disease now comes to the hospital due to problems 
with vision. She complains that while turning her head, the image of the previous target still 
persists for a few seconds before she can see the new target. This phenomenon is seen in 
which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
The persistence of visual image even after shifting gaze is called palinopsia. It is seen in Balint’s 
syndrome. Balint’s syndrome results due to low flow in the watershed areas between distal PCA and MCA 
territories. It is characterized by the following: • Palinopsia - persistence of a visual image despite gazing at another scene • Asimultagnosia - difficulty to focus on more than one item in the visual field • Optic ataxia - Inability to reach accurately under visual guidance • Ocular apraxia - Inability to direct gaze accurately to a new target Claude's syndrome is a distinctive brainstem syndrome characterized by ipsilateral third nerve 
palsy with contralateral hemiataxia. It is due to an intrinsic or extrinsic lesion in the midbrain. Note: While some authors use the term simultanagnosia, others use asimultanagnosia instead. A 
few authors also use these two terminologies interchangeably.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following features do you not expect to see in a patient with Balint's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
1121 
Sold by @itachibot Opsoclonus is not seen in Balint's syndrome. The features of Balint’s syndrome are: • Optic ataxia - the inability to guide the arm to reach a certain object in the visual field • Simultanagnosia - the inability to perceive more than one object at a time. In other words, it is 
the inability to recognize multiple elements in a visual presentation, one object or some elements 
of a scene can be appreciated but not the display as a whole. • Ocular apraxia - the inability to control voluntary purposeful eye movements • Palinopsia - the persistence of a visual image even after the stimulus has been removed Note: While some authors use the term simultanagnosia, others use asimultanagnosia instead. A 
few authors also use these two terminologies interchangeably.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient presents with ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiplegia. What is the 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiplegia is seen in Weber’s syndrome. Weber’s syndrome occurs due to infarction in the distribution of the penetrating branches of the 
PCA. It affects the cerebral peduncle, especially medially, and damages III cranial nerve and the 
pyramidal fibers. It results in contralateral hemiplegia and ipsilateral oculomotor palsy. Claude's syndrome is a distinctive brainstem syndrome characterized by ipsilateral third cranial 
nerve palsy with contralateral hemiataxia. This is due to an intrinsic or extrinsic lesion in the 
midbrain.

questions.question: Question 7: Which among the following is wrong regarding Weber’s syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ipsilateral paralysis of the lower face is not seen in Weber's syndrome. However, there is 
contralateral paralysis of the lower face. Weber syndrome is caused by infarction in the distribution of the penetrating branches of the 
posterior cerebral artery (PCA). It affects the cerebral peduncle, especially medially, with damage 
to the fascicle of cranial nerve III and the pyramidal fibers. The resultant clinical findings are contralateral hemiplegia of the face, arm, and leg secondary to 
corticospinal and corticobulbar tract involvement, and ipsilateral oculomotor paresis including a 
dilated pupil. Structure damaged

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient presented with loss of upgaze and convergence-retraction nystagmus. What is the 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The presence of convergence-retraction nystagmus and loss of upgaze is seen in Parinaud's 
syndrome. It is caused by a lesion in the dorsal midbrain. The following tetrad of symptoms are seen: • Loss of upgaze • Light-near dissociation • Convergence-retraction nystagmus • Lid retraction Convergence■retraction nystagmus is irregular, jerky nystagmus in which both eyeballs 
rhythmically converge and retract into the orbit, particularly on attempting an upward gaze. Nothnagel syndrome is associated with oculomotor palsy and contralateral limb ataxia. 
Underlying structures involved are the superior cerebellar peduncle and tectum of the midbrain.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient presented with left-sided hemiplegia and examination revealed right-sided 
abducens nerve palsy and facial nerve palsy. Further investigation revealed a right-sided 
pontine haemorrhage. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ipsilateral abducens and facial nerve palsy with contralateral hemiplegia are seen in Millard–
Gubler syndrome. In this syndrome, there is a ventral pontine injury (lesion in abducens fascicle) that causes lateral 
rectus palsy. 1123

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following differentiates Foville’s syndrome from Millard-Gubler syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Lateral gaze palsy is a feature of Foville’s Syndrome which is a result of dorsal pontine injury. Millard-Gubler syndrome occurs due to ventral pontine injury. Lateral gaze palsy does not occur 
in this condition because the abducens fascicle is injured rather than the nucleus. CNS lesion

questions.question:
Question 11: Thrombosis of posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes  
.
questions.explanation:
Thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) causes lateral medullary syndrome or 
Wallenberg syndrome. PICA is a branch of the fourth part of the vertebral artery, which is a branch of the first part of 
subclavian artery.

questions.question:
Question 12: Wallenberg syndrome is most commonly caused by thrombosis of which of the following 
arteries?
questions.explanation:
Thrombosis of the vertebral artery is most commonly implicated in Wallenberg syndrome. Wallenberg syndrome, also called lateral medullary syndrome, is due to occlusion of the ipsilateral 
vertebral artery in most cases. In the remainder, posterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion is 
responsible. Wallenberg / lateral medullary syndrome affects the following structures: • Descending tract and nucleus of cranial nerve V - Ipsilateral impaired sensation over half of the 
face • IX and X cranial nerves - Ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex • Nucleus of tractus solitarius - Ipsilateral loss of taste • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea • Spinocerebellar tract - Ipsilateral ataxia • Descending sympathetic tract - Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome • Lateral spinothalamic tract - Contralateral impaired pain and thermal sensation over half of the 
body. 1125 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following features do you not expect to see in a patient with Wallenberg 
syndrome?

options.d: Impaired sensation on ipsilateral half of face

questions.explanation:
The pyramidal tracts are not affected in Wallenberg syndrome and therefore hemiplegia is not 
seen. Wallenberg / lateral medullary syndrome affects the following structures: • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V - I/L impaired sensation over half of face • IX and X CN - I/L paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex • Nucleus of Tractus Solitarius – I/L loss of taste • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea • Spinocerebellar tract – I/L ataxia • Descending sympathetic tract – I/L Horner’s syndrome • Lateral spinothalamic tract – C/L impaired pain and thermal sensation over half of the body.

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with medial 
medullary syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Horner’s syndrome is not a feature of medial medullary syndrome. Medial medullary syndrome occurs due to the occlusion of the vertebral artery or a branch of the 
vertebral or basilar artery. The features of medial medullary syndrome are • CN XII - Ipsilateral paralysis of the tongue • Pyramidal tract - Contralateral hemiplegia • Medial lemniscus - Impaired tactile and proprioception over the contralateral half of the body Horner’s syndrome occurs due to a lesion involving the sympathetic fibres. It is seen in lateral 
medullary syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 15: Which is the most common site of bleed in patients with intracerebral hypertensive 
haemorrhage? 1113 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most common site for intracerebral hypertensive hemorrhage is the putamen. The most common type of intracranial haemorrhage is an intraparenchymal i.e., intracerebral 
haemorrhage. It is most often caused by a hypertensive bleed. Most common sites of intracerebral hypertensive bleed: • Putamen (basal ganglia) • Thalamus • Cerebellum • Pons. 1126 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Raised intracranial tension is not associated with which of the following manifestations?
questions.explanation:
Raised ICT is not associated with paraparesis. Manifestations of raised ICT include: • Hypertension • Bradycardia • Respiratory depression • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy • Seizures Paraparesis is usually caused by a spinal lesion such as thoracic myelopathy and neoplasms 
causing compression of the spinal cord. Rare intracranial causes of paraparesis are: • Parasagittal meningioma • Occlusion of unpaired anterior cerebral artery • Cerebral venous thrombosis affecting the sagittal sinus.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is a component of Cushing’s triad?
questions.explanation: Bradycardia is a component of Cushing's triad. Cushing’s triad is characteristically seen in raised ICT. Its components are as follows: • Hypertension • Bradycardia • Respiratory depression.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 62-year-old man presents to the casualty with a severe headache, fever, and vomiting for 
the past 5 hours. There is no history of trauma. CT head is shown below. What is the most 
common cause for his presentation? 1114 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of non-traumatic subarachnoid haemorrhage. The most common 
cause for this condition is the rupture of a berry aneurysm, also known as a saccular aneurysm. CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space, which is suggestive of SAH. 
Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at 
this location. Most unruptured intracranial aneurysms are completely asymptomatic. Prodromal symptoms 
occasionally suggest the site of the enlarging unruptured aneurysm. For example, cranial nerve III 
palsy with loss of ipsilateral light reflex and focal pain above or behind the eye suggests an 
expanding aneurysm at the junction of the posterior communicating artery and internal carotid 1127 
Sold by @itachibot artery. Ruptured aneurysms cause an excruciating thunderclap headache followed by a transient loss of 
consciousness. Non-contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice for SAH. LP shows xanthochromatic CSF. Treatment involves clipping or coiling the aneurysm to eliminate the risk of rebleeding.

questions.question:
Question 19: Which of the following structures is most likely to be compressed by an aneurysm of the 
posterior communicating artery?
questions.explanation:
Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery will most likely compress the oculomotor 
nerve. This is because the posterior communicating artery is anatomically located very close to the 
oculomotor nerve. Patients with an aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery can present with symptoms of 
oculomotor nerve palsy such as: • Unilateral ptosis (LPS) • Outward eye deviation (MR) • Dilated pupil. The nerves controlling the pupils are located very superficially and these are always affected due 
to the mass effect of the aneurysm. Therefore the pupil sparing third nerve palsies are unlikely to 
be due to an aneurysm. Pupil-sparing oculomotor nerve palsy is often assumed to be caused by ischemic injuries such as 
hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Expanding unruptured aneurysms can occasionally lead to prodromal symptoms which suggest 
the location of the aneurysm.

questions.question: Question 20: At which of the following locations does a Berry aneurysm have the highest risk of rupture?
questions.explanation:
The size and site of aneurysm are important in predicting the risk of rupture. Aneurysms with the 
following features have a greater risk of rupture: • Size >7 mm in diameter • Located at the top of the basilar artery (i.e origin of the posterior cerebral artery) • Located near the origin of the posterior communicating artery. The most common location of Berry aneurysm is the anterior communicating artery.

questions.question:
Question 21: The CT finding of a patient is shown below. What is the most common cause for this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given image is suggestive of a subdural hematoma and it most commonly results from injury 
to the bridging dural veins. 1128 
Sold by @itachibot Subdural hematoma refers to the haemorrhage between the dura and arachnoid mater. The image 
of the CT scan reveals a hyperdense crescentic lesion. Mass effect with midline displacement can 
also be seen. Causes of SDH are: • Trauma • Anticoagulants • Antiplatelets • Alcohol abuse • Shaken baby syndrome. Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice. Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhage are: • Typically unilateral • Crescent-like distribution (concavo-convex) around the periphery of the brain • Not limited by sutures and can fill dural reflections • Chronic subdural hemorrhage: Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT • Acute subdural hemorrhage: Hyperdense collections on CT

questions.question:
Question 22: The CT scan of a patient who was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident is 
shown below. Between what structures does blood accumulate in this condition? 1116 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Outer table and inner table of the skull
options.d: Periosteum and aponeurotic layer of scalp

questions.explanation:
The given CT image is suggestive of extradural haemorrhage (EDH). In this condition, blood 
accumulates between the inner table of the skull and the dura mater. The typical presentation is an initial loss of consciousness following trauma, a complete transient 
recovery (lucid interval), and a rapid progression of neurological deterioration. This condition is treated by rapid surgical evacuation and ligation or cautery of the damaged 
vessel.

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following statements is false regarding extradural hemorrhage?

options.c: Middle meningeal artery bleed is the most common source

questions.explanation:
In extradural hemorrhage (EDH), CT brain does not show a crescentric opacity. It shows a 
lentiform opacity.

questions.question:
Question 24: A 50-year-old hypertensive man presented with an acute-onset headache for the past 2 hours, 
neck stiffness, nausea, and vomiting. He claims it is the worst headache of his life. There are 
no focal neurological deficits and his CT scan shows blood in the Sylvian fissure. What is the 
most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This patient's clinical features of sudden-onset headache with neck stiffness, nausea, and vomiting 
with no neurological deficits is suggestive of a diagnosis of subarachnoid haemorrhage. The 
presence of blood in the Sylvian fissure confirms this diagnosis. 1129 
Sold by @itachibot Trauma is the most common cause. However, spontaneous sub-arachnoid bleeding occurs most 
often due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm. Most of them are found in the anterior circulation, 
mostly on the circle of Willis. The three most common locations are: • Terminal ICA • MCA bifurcation • Top of the basilar artery. A non-contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice. LP shows xanthochromatic CSF. Treatment involves clipping or coiling the aneurysm to eliminate the risk of rebleeding.

questions.question:
Question 25: A 53-year-old man was admitted with a history of a cerebrovascular accident. On the second 
day, he becomes drowsy with minimal response. CT finding is shown in the image below. 
What will be your next line of management?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario describes a 53 year old patient admitted in view of a cerebrovascular accident 
developing neurologic deterioration (drowsy with minimal response) on the second day, and CT 
brain showing significant edema of MCA territory with midline shift. The next line of 
management is decompressive surgery. Cerebral edema is a potential complication in 5-10% of patients with strokes, leading to 
obtundation and brain herniation. The severity of edema is highest on the second or third day 
after the stroke and can last for around 10 days. Medical management may not be successful in case of significant edema or infarcts involving the 
cerebellum. Decompressive surgery is recommended for patients who are less than 60 years old and 
experience deterioration  48 hours, despite receiving medical therapy. Hypodensity on head CT 
within the first 6 hours of stroke onset, involving  one-third of the MCA territory, early midline 
shift, and a diffusion-weighted imaging volume on MRI within 6 hours  80 mL are predictors of 
severe cerebral edema.

questions.question:
Question 26: A 62-year-old man presents to the ER with headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 5 
hours. A CT image is shown below. Physical examination shows positive Kernig’s and 
Brudzinski’s signs. Vitals: Temp - 101 F, BP - 120/88 mmHg, PR - 110 beats/min, pupils 
reactive. What is the next best step? 1118 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and the treatment of choice for this 
condition is surgical clipping. CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space, which is suggestive of SAH. 
Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at 
this location. SAH can present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign, and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic 
meningitis or encephalitis. Treatment with the calcium channel antagonist nimodipine (60 mg PO every 4 h) improves 
outcome, by preventing ischemic injury. Option A: Vancomycin + ceftriaxone is the recommended therapy for bacterial meningitis. 
Meningitis does not show hyper-attenuated subarachnoid space. 1130 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: IV Tenecteplase is used for ischemic stroke without bleeding complications. 1131 
Sold by @itachibot Peripheral Neuropathy
